dataBase.name: Nakhla Metorite
dataBase.information: Nakhla is a Martian meteorite that fell in Egypt on June 28, 1911

dataBase.name: Evidence of Water
dataBase.information: Nakhla is the first Martian meteorite to be discovered to show signs of water existing on Mars. The meteorite contains carbonates and hydrous minerals, formed by chemical reactions that could only occur in the presence of liquid water.

dataBase.name: Origin
dataBase.information: Nakhla, like all Martian meteorites, are rocks that initially formed on Mars before being ejected into space by the impact of an asteroid or comet. After floating through space for an unknown amount of time, they eventually fell to Earth.

dataBase.name: The Nakhla dog
dataBase.information: An Egyptian farmer who witnessed Nakhla fall to Earth claimed that a fragment of the meteorite landed on a very unlucky dog. The witnessed claimed that the dog was vaporized instantly on impact. Since no remains of the dog were ever found, the authenticity of the story is dubious. Nevertheless, the story of the Nakhla dog has become a legend among astronomers and scientists

dataBase.name: Composition
dataBase.information: Nakhla is an igneous rock that is rich in augite. It was formed from basaltic magma about 1.3 billion years ago. Nakhla most likely formed on the volcanic regions of Mars, such as Tharsis or Elysium.
